title: Beach House's '7' is a Dreamy Masterpiece
summary: Elizabeth sings about reminiscing about that special moment when it all began with lines like “Reminding you of something you forgot.” “Dark Spring” is the perfect blend of the Beach House we know and love and the change we saw on their last two albums. “Lemon Glow” carries some of the melodies from “Bloom”, Beach House’s first album released in 2008. The sixth track on the album is a beautiful love song that feels like the perfect end to the first half of the album.

content.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("h2",null,"Track-by-Track Review"),mdx("p",null,"This album starts off on a high note with \u201CDark Spring\u201D. This is track number one and the title track, a perfect introduction to Beach House\u2019s take on dream pop on this record. It\u2019s a song about the start of a relationship. Elizabeth sings about reminiscing about that special moment when it all began with lines like \u201CReminding you of something you forgot.\u201D \u201CDark Spring\u201D is the perfect blend of the Beach House we know and love and the change we saw on their last two albums."),mdx("p",null,"The second track on the album is \u201CDive.\u201D This is the first single from the album released back in October of 2018. \u201CDive\u201D is one of the more upbeat songs on the album and one of the best as well. It\u2019s a song about falling in love, with lyrics like \u201CYou fell in love with the sound of the ocean.\u201D This song is a great example of how this album is both nostalgic and fresh at the same time. Something Beach House do so well."),mdx("p",null,"The third track on the album is the second single released, \u201CLemon Glow\u201D. This is one of the more electronic-sounding songs on the album and the first instance of Beach House\u2019s trademark layered harmonies coming through. This is also the first hint of nostalgia that comes from this album, as \u201CLemon Glow\u201D carries some of the melodies from \u201CBloom\u201D, Beach House\u2019s first album released in 2008."),mdx("p",null,"The fourth track on the album is \u201CSkipping\u201D. This is another one of the more upbeat songs and a return to the Beach House we know and love. This song isn\u2019t about falling in love like others on the album, it\u2019s about staying in love."),mdx("p",null,"The fifth track on the album is \u201CGirl of the Year\u201D. This is one of the more interesting choices of song order on the album. It\u2019s one of the slower songs but it has a lot of energy. It\u2019s about the anxiety of being in a relationship and feeling like you\u2019re being held back by the girl you love."),mdx("p",null,"The sixth track on the album is \u201CDrinking Coffee\u201D. This is a beautiful love song that feels like the perfect end to the first half of the album. This song is about reminiscing on the moments that brought you together and feeling lucky someone is in your life. It\u2019s a beautiful song with a catchy chorus, great guitar riffs and a simple yet effective drum beat."),mdx("p",null,"The seventh track on the album is \u201CLurking\u201D. This is one of the more \u201Cout there\u201D tracks on the album, mostly thanks to the synthesizer-heavy instrumental. This song is about the moments that make you feel anxious, like waiting for a phone call or a text from someone."),mdx("p",null,"The eighth track on the album is \u201CTremendous Darkness\u201D. This is a slower and more moody track about accepting the feelings we have that we aren\u2019t always proud of. It\u2019s a song about knowing that you can\u2019t always hide from the things that make you feel bad, but you also can\u2019t let them control you."),mdx("p",null,"The ninth and final track on the album is \u201CDays of Candy\u201D. This is a softer and more minimal track compared to the rest of the album. It\u2019s a song about the things you do to distract yourself from your own thoughts and how easy it is to forget how short life can be. It\u2019s a very sweet and thoughtful way to end the album."),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CDark Spring\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,'"Dive."'),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CLemon Glow\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CSkipping\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CGirl of the Year\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CDrinking Coffee\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CLurking\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CTremendous Darkness\u201D"),mdx("h2",null,"\u201CDays of Candy\u201D"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Martian" Is a Triumph of Science Fiction

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Ridley Scott\u2019s new movie, The Martian, is based on a novel of the same name by Andy Weir. It\u2019s about an astronaut called Mark Watney who gets stranded on Mars after his crewmates think he\u2019s dead and leave without him. This might seem as just another case of annoying Hollywood over-simplification: after all, we get so many bioengineered super-geniuses with computer uplink implants that they can become trapped in remote locations via their own stupidity. But there\u2019s more to it than that.
In both book and film, the humanity of Watney comes out in everything he does to survive: logical thinking (how can I eat this potato again?), ingenuity (I need water; how do I distill it from our CO2 filters), courage (explore the abandoned outpost), and compassion (contact my family). He also has a lot of fun with his predicament, cracking jokes through his video log and even going disco.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: Bts's 'Love Yourself: Tear' Is a Triumph

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`In a world where every band is a boy band, BTS stands out. The Korean sextet has made a name for itself as not just another boy band but one that plays its own instruments and has choreographed dance routines that are so intricate they sometimes require special stage lighting.
Armed with these weapons, BTS has twice cracked the top 10 on the Billboard 200 album chart with its Love Yourself series. And the latest installment of this series \u2014 which doubles as its sixth EP \u2014 is no exception.
Furthermore, it\u2019s the strongest of the bunch.
It\u2019s impossible to talk about BTS without mentioning their massive following beyond Korea: Vivid, obsessive ARMYs (as they call them) who follow their every move and buy everything associated with them. This is why many people assume they are only famous because of social media and pandering ads (which is true). However, anyone who listens to their music will tell you that they deserve all this success. \u201CLove Yourself: Tear\u201D proves it once again.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Rappers That Will Make You Want to Get Out on the Floor and Dance

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"As hip-hop continues to shed its once-maligned reputation and become increasingly popular, we\u2019ve seen a related boom in mainstream rap music. More than ever before, people are listening to and talking about rappers. But with so much of the genre becoming commodified and predictable, it can be difficult for new artists to stand out among the noise. Fortunately, just because most popular rap fails to break any molds doesn\u2019t mean that the genre is completely devoid of creative talent. In fact, there are a number of rappers who have been working hard to maintain their integrity while still appealing to a larger audience. If you\u2019re ready to put on your dancing shoes and get out on the floor with one of these 10 amazing rappers who will make you want to dance:"))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "Whiplash" Is a Tense and Exhilarating Look at the World of Jazz
Foster the People's 'Sacred Hearts Club' Is a Fun Ride
"The Grapes of Wrath" Is a Classic of American Literature
Charlie Puth's 'Voicenotes' Is a Solid Effort

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:t,...e}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...e,components:t,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Charlie Puth has been on a roll lately, with three top 40 hits in the last two years. He\u2019s also worked with some pretty big names (including one we\u2019ll get to shortly). Now, he\u2019s back with another new album, titled \u201CVoicenotes.\u201D It\u2019s a solid effort that shows growth and maturity, as well as keeping Puth\u2019s fun and lighthearted style.
At its core, Voicenotes is an acoustic pop album. However, it goes deeper than just putting electric guitars aside; these songs are stripped right down to the bare bones. There\u2019s still plenty of production value\u2014especially on the third track\u2014but it feels like Puth made a conscious decision not to hide behind anything.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "The Theory of Everything" Is a Touching Biopic of Stephen Hawking
Haim's 'Something to Tell You' Is a Delightful Pop Album

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`It\u2019s been almost three years since we heard new music from HAIM, the sister trio from Calabasas that burst onto the music scene in 2014 with their debut album \u2018Days Are Gone.\u2019
With their sophomore album, \u2018Something to Tell You,\u2019 HAIM continues to be optimistic and uplifting with their new music. The album is a mix of upbeat pop tracks and slower ballads that showcase the sisters\u2019 harmony and vocals. Even if you aren't a fan of pop music, it's worth giving this album a listen.
The trio had been working on this album for some time before releasing it. In September 2016, they released three singles; \u201CRight Now,\u201D \u201CNew York Excuse\u201D and \u201CSentimentality.\u201D
And after a year-long hiatus following the release of these songs, HAIM announced via Instagram in June 2017 that they would finally be releasing their second studio album (and first extended play) later that year.
Luckily for us, they stuck to their word and released the nine-track EP on Sept. 14, just in time for our listening pleasure. Here are some of our favorite tracks from HAIM's 'Something To Tell You' Album:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: "Selma" Is a Powerful and Moving Historical Drama

intro.compiledSource: const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,"It\u2019s been more than a century since the fight for voting rights was so prominent in American society. Films like \u201CSelma\u201D are necessary to remind viewers of this period in our history and the crucial role that certain people played in ensuring voting rights are protected. Before many others, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., along with other civil rights leaders, attempted to register African-Americans to vote in Selma, Alabama. It was here where police brutality and attacks on protesters were prevalent and where media attention centered around televised trials of two men accused of murdering local Black residents. The town was also home to Selma\u2019s most famous resident at the time: Collin W. Lewis, also known as \u201Cthe Lion of Selma\u201D \u2013 a prominent civil rights leader who had grown up there after his family fled Greenwood as part of the Great Migration from 1916-1921. In 1965, Lewis recruited Dr. King to come speak at Selma High School about voting rights. It was here where their partnership began and culminated in the historic march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge on March 7th, 1965 \u2013 known today as Bloody Sunday because those marching were violently attacked by law enforcement officers (including tear gas, billy clubs, and bull whips), leaving many injured and 26 hospitalized (Voting Rights Timeline)."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
